text: We'll hear argument now in Number 99-9136, Earthy Daniels v. United States.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
May I ask whether the record shows whether the petitioner challenged those '78 and '81 convictions in a timely manner on direct appeal at the State and/or Federal level?
I don't believe that's in the record.
You know, it seems to me that the opportunity to make those challenges very likely occurred when the convictions became final.

That's true, Your Honor, and I'm sure that there was, in California, a procedure for direct appeal and, lacking that, also collateral review of those convictions, but that's not what's at issue today.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
With certain exceptions.
--With the exception of a conviction that was entered in violation of Gideon v. Wainwright, that's correct, Justice Stevens.
You think that's the only such exception?
I think that that is the line that the Court drew in Custis, Justice O'Connor.
Well, how about a so called Brady violation, where the facts aren't known until maybe immediately before the sentencing proceeding in the new crime?
Well, there are two distinctions between that kind of a situation and the Gideon situation.
Well, what about a DNA claim in a death case coming up later?

Well, the second... I think, Justice O'Connor, that is the second distinction in your hypothetical, that the hypothetical posits that this was information about a constitutional claim that could not with due diligence have been obtained, I'm assuming within any time for bringing an appropriate appeal or collateral challenge.
Do you make that argument even if it's a Gideon violation?
--Under this Court's decision in Custis he may at the Federal sentencing raise it, and I--
No, no, not at the Federal sentencing.
--That would be a procedural default, Justice Stevens, and I think it would bar the defendant from coming back even if there were otherwise a right to come back under applicable procedure.
Would that be true even if the sentence had not been served where there was a Gideon violation?
The sentence of the... the underlying conviction--
This would always have to have been served, wouldn't it?
--Well, if the underlying conviction sentence had not been served, then the defendant's remedy would be to go back into the jurisdiction that entered it and see if he can comply with--
He couldn't then go in on a 2255 and call that to the court's attention and get relief, in your view?

--I don't think so, Justice Stevens, because he has the right to do that under Custis at the Federal sentencing proceeding itself, and the failure to bring that claim at a timely point in the proceeding, when it is available, would constitute a default, and then he would be left with the argument--
Even if he had... even if it was inadequate assistance of counsel?
--Well, inadequate assistance of counsel isn't even permitted to be brought under this Court's decision in Custis with respect to the underlying conviction.

Yes, but it's the therefore part that I guess is giving us all the trouble, and the reason it's giving me trouble is, number 1... of course, I was a dissenter in Custis, so maybe I'm looking for trouble--
I'd first like to address the question of what Custis left open.
